div1.p: Carter reports on his investigation of a foreign sailor's illness and death, in Sabine, Texas.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, November 20, 1918
div1.opener:
Investigation of alleged
case of Yellow Fever at
Sabine, Texas.
Assistant Surgeon General H.R. Carter
copy for file
November 20, 1918.
The Surgeon General,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to submit this report of my investigation of a
case alleged to be Yellow Fever aboard the S/S Belaire at Sabine, Texas.

I first saw Acting Assistant Winter at Port Arthur, Texas, and
obtained his statement, then visited the State Quarantine Station at Sabine
and got the statement of Dr. Chilton, Quarantine Officer, who had the records
of his office with him. The Belaire returned to Sabine from Galveston while
I was at the Quarantine Station and, after the vessel was passed, in I saw the
Master and got such data from him as seemed needed. I then returned to Port
Arthur and again talked to Dr. Winter, on some points that after my visit to
Sabine seemed to need elucidation. On account of the return of the Belaire
to Sabine it was unnecessary to visit Galveston, so asking for information
on one point from Wilson, by wire, I came to New Orleans to look up the mat-
ter of the Fruit vessel on which this case had been previously. Dr. Corput
had the data needed here. On account of some discrepancies between Dr. Corput's
record and my own it was necessary to get additional information by wire from
Dr. Wilson and Dr. Chilton - this has been done.

I am sending (1) what I believe to be the facts in the case and
(2) the statement of Dr. Winter, Dr. Chilton and the Master of the Belaire
as made to me, on which some of my findings are based.

(I) OneJuan Llanez, 24 years, Spanish, left S/S Quinistan, a fruit vessel, at New
Orleans, La., October 27, 1918, 4 days out from Tela, Honduras, (Immigration
record New Orleans, La., by Dr. Corput) shipped aboard S/S Bellaire on Novem-
ber 2, evening. Bellaire left New Orleans on November 3, arrived at Sabine
Quarantine November 4, with “all well aboard and no sickness enroute” (affidavit
of Master and Inspection of State Quarantine Officer at Sabine)

Vessel was cleared at Quarantine andbut, another vessel being in the berth
she should take, the Bellaire laid at anchor at the Quarantine Boarding place. At
the request of the Master, Dr. Chilteron went aboard again on November 6, and
found this man, Llanez, sick. He considered the case Yellow Fever and so re-
ported. He visited the vessel again on the morning of November 7, about 10
or 11 A.M. During this visit Dr. Winter came aboard and saw the sick man also.
Dr. Chilton visited the vessel again on the 8th, about 10 A.M., and found the man
dead, the Master stating that he died at 6 A.M. of that day. He was buried that
afternoon on the beach and the vessel left for Galveston that evening or night.
One other man was sick when, or shortly before, she left Sabine, but all reported
well (on Wilson's inspections) on arrival at Galveston Quarantine on November
9, at 4:30 P.M. The Master states Llanez became sick on the evening of Novem-
ber 5; he worked that day. The above dates and statement are verified as far
as possible by the records.
(2) Statement of Dr. Winter November 16, 1918.

His information is as given him by the Captain of the Bellaire, except
the clinical history:

Seaman arrived New Orleans, November 2, via fruit steamer, from South
American port, and immediately, November 2, joined the Bellaire. First day
after, this, man got sick; arrived Sabine November 4, and found ill by State
Quarantine Officer, who made diagnosis of Yellow Fever. Was seen by Dr. Winter
3
on November 6, early in the morning, who concurred in the diagnosis - died
November 7, at night.
Clinical History-

Man could not speak English and when seen was very sick. Skin very
yellow and man much depressed. Had been nauseated. Do not know that he vomited
but thinks he did before his (Winter's) visit - ascribed to calomel taken. Had a large
and very offensive stool. Liver but slightly, if at all, enlarged; very tender
as was all of the abdomen. Some tympanites but not marked - no petechiae. Gums
not bleeding but swollen. Tongue like sand paper, never saw a tongue like it
before, not a malarial tongue. Am very familiar with malaria fever and am posi-
tive this can be excluded. Pulse below normal, temperature about 102°. Urine
dark, Albuminous - no great deal of albumen, but distinctly albuminous. On
questioning further - Said about 5% by volume of wet albumen. Suggested to Dr.
Corput to disintor and make autopsy but he said it was too late.
(NOTE - Dr. Carter.

I did not ask what test for Albumen was used. Naturally from the per-
centage given I judged he used heat and nitric acid. Dr. Corput states that
(in answer to a question) Dr. Winter said he used cold nitric acid - the “ring
test” and obtained a slight orbut definite ring.)

The above statement is made from memory, Dr. Winter having no notes
of the case, except the dates as given in his telegrams and letter to the
Bureau.

Statement Dr. ChiltonChiltern, State Quarantine Officer, Sabine, Texas, and verified
as to names, dates, etc., by Quarantine Records at his office November 16, 1918.
No clinical record kept; the clinical history is from memory.

The subject of this history could speak no English and the interpretor
very little, so such history as came from the sick man is necessarily imper-
fect. One YlanezJuan Yanez, Mexican, 23 years, arrived New Orleans, November 2, 1918,
4
on fruit vessel 4 days out from a port in Honduras, shipped aboard Bellaire
as pump man on November 3. Bellaire arrived Saturday, November 4 - all
aboard “well enroute and on arrival” (affidavit of Master and Dr. Chiltern's)
examination of crew). Vessel cleared and could have docked but another vessel
was at the dock ahead of her and she laid at anchor to the morning of November 6,
when Dr. C. visited her again at the request of the Captain and found this man
sick, temperature 102.5°, in a well screened Hospital. Visited him again on
November 7, about 10 or 11 A.M. Dr. Winter came aboard during this visit and
saw him also. Dr. Winter came down on a tug; sent by the agents. Went aboard
again about 10 A.M., November 8, found man dead; Captain said he died at 6 A.M.
He was buried that afternoon and the vessel sailed for Galveston Quarantine
that evening.
Clinical History:

First visit on Nov. 6 - Injected eyes, red conjunctiva and from his motions
much frontal headache. Pain in stomach - not vomiting but apparently trying
to vomit, bending over bed; could not find out from any one whether he had
vomited or not. Skin yellow. History taken that day and influenced diagno-
sis, i.e. just off fruit steamer and from a Yellow Fever country. Made diag-
nosis of Yellow Fever.

Second visit Nov. 7 -Skin a deeper yellow, temperature about the same,
Eyes blazing, not so much complaint, otherwise about the same. Pulse softer
and more thready; about 120 the first day, not quite so frequent the second day
(NOTE discrepancy with Dr. Winter's account taken at this same time ) Still nau-
seated; tongue very dry, sharpppointed, coated in the middle - as dry as a chip-
same both days.

Urine not examined; could not get any. The man watching him said
he made none. One bowel movement seen - dark, watery diarrhoeal action. Dont
-5-
know that he had taken any medicine for his bowels. He gave him none. Could not
find if he vomited at any time but did not see him do so, or see any vomit. Urine
was not taken by Dr. Winter or any one else. Dr. Winter stayed about 15 minutes
aboard ship.

Buried 10 or 12 hours after death. Saw corps at 10 or 11 A.M. Body
showed dark spots of the calves of legs. Whole body yellow: Saw no froth
or dark material about mouth at any time.
(Note by Carter

I was impressed by the straight forward honesty of Dr. Chiltern,
telling just what he had observed. He was more interesting in determining
the proper measures to take as a Quarantine Officer than about the patholog-
ical accuracy of the diagnosis. It is needless to say that his action in
holding the vessel in Quarantine as soon as this case was discovered and fi-
nally remanding her to Galveston Quarantine was correct. A case of sickness
occurring under such uncertain circumstances, unless known not to be Yellow
Fever, should be treated as if it were Yellow Fever. This is what Dr. Chilton
did.)
Statement Master of Bellaire.

Dates as given by Dr. Chilton concerning his vessel correct. Man's
name is “Llanez” not “Yanez”. Became sick evening November 5. Sent for Doctor
next morning; Worked all day of the 5th, so far as he knows. One other man sick
when vessel left but was well before he reached Galveston. He gave his card
to Dr. Wilson at Galveston; Thinks it was his passport as it had his photograph
on it. It gives the name of the vessel he was last on before the Bellaire.
Statement Dr. Winter November 17, 1918.

Got a small specimen of urine, but enough to examine, Passed while he
-6-
was with the sick man, in a vessel which he had had emptied of the stool..It was
high colored, rather than dark, not smoky, like febrile. urine

Is very familiar with malarial fever - as it occurs in this vicinity. Not
familiar with Malarial Hemoglobinuria (Black Water Fever) Dont know that it oc-
curs in this vicinity. Is positive that he saw the sick man on the 6th, not on the
7th, as Dr. Chilton says, and that the Captain told him that the man had been sick
almost as soon as he came aboard and had not worked except an hour or so.

The history of this case is too meagre to certainly determine its nature.
The diagnosis of Yellow Fever by Dr. Winter is based on (1) Yellowness of skin;
(2) Extreme prostration; and (3) exclusion of other diseases - malaria and gall
duct obstructions, especially liable to cause jaundice with which he was familiar.

That of Dr. Chilton was based on (1) Jaundice; (2) extreme sickness; (3)
the infected face and headache, and (4) to some extent, from the place of origin
of the patient - A Central American port via a fruit vessel which he thought
the patient left on November 2; judgement the diagnosis could be (a) Yellow
Fever; (b) Malarial HemoglobinuriaBlack Water Fever; (c) any fulminating infection - as influenza
or even such a peritoneal infection from any cause.

As sustaining the diagnosis of Yellow Fever we have (1) the appearance
of the face as described by Dr. Chilton; (2) Jaundice; and (3) death. These
appearances would occur in the fatal case of Yellow Fever. As against this di-
agnosis we have (1) the early onset and rapid jau development of jaundice. The
skin was found by Dr. Chilton “Yellow” on the first day of sickness and “very
yellow” on the second by both Dr. Chilton and Dr. Winter; (2) The early death.
It is extremely rare for a case of Yellow Fever to die as quickly as this man
died. Nevertheless there is always a possibliity of the man having been sick,
altho working several, days before he was so reported, or of the case being one
of fulminating severity. (3) Black vomit would be very apt, though not certain
7
to show in a dying case of Yellow Fever and this sign is so marked that it would
scarcely escape notice by any at tendant however stupid and traces of it should
show to the Doctor on the patient's face and bedding - none was observed. (4)
The absence of haemorragic symptoms - Gums and tongue, etc., is noted by Dr. Winter
and their presence not observed by Dr. Chiltern. I do not recall that I have found
such signs missing in cases that die and it must be extremely rare.

(5) With regard to the urine. Attention is called to the apparent discrepancy
of Dr. Winter's statement to me and those of Dr. Chiltern and of Dr. Winter's to
Dr. Corput. It is to be noted that the urine of a case of Yellow Fever, heavily
jaundiced, very much depressed and 18 hours before death should be more than dis-
tinctly albuminous. It should be loaded with albumen.

It is a question whether the “previous environment” of the patient should be
seriously considered as a factor, certainly I have never done so where the clinical ev-
idence was at all positive, yet possibly we should note the length of time from his
leaving the Quimistan considered the last possible place of infection, to the re-
ported date of the development of fever - October 27 to November 5, 9 days. This
is well beyond the recognized period on incubation of Yellow Fever, which has not
been noted to extend beyond 6 days and 2 hours. This of course if of weight only
as applying to infection from this source.

The evidence for Black Water Fever is (1) the early advent of marked yellow-
ness; (2) the rapid collapse and death, and (3) the suppression or partial suppres-
sion of urine. If we accept the statement of Dr. Winter as to the color of urine,
this is absolutely negatived by it, otherwise it would be a very probable diagno-
sis.

The evidence for a full fulminating infection say- influenza is (1) the
facies and headache observed by Dr. Chiltern; (2) marked prostration and jaundice
and (3) the quick death. This syndrome has been noted a rumor of times in
8
this epidemic.

With the data on hand a certain diagnosis is not possible to me. The
balance of evidence seems to me to be dicidedly against Yellow Fever. Consider-
ing the presence of the epidemic, I am inclined to the diagnosis of a fulminant
case of Influenza as the most probable one, altho I have seen exactly those symp-
toms in a case of appendicitis.
It is greatly to be regretted that an autopsy was not held.
